data.title: Mendes Research Group
data.text:
Congratulations Dr. Joseph Masison!

We're organizing ICSB 2023.

Postdoc position to develop computational methods for COPASI.

Farewell to Dr. Baig.

Farewell to Dr. Koshy-Chenthittayil.

Hasan Baig joins our team.

We're organizing ICSB 2020!

Postdoc position to develop computational methods for COPASI.

Farewell to Dr. Abhishekh Gupta!

Farewell to Dr. Jignesh Parmar!

Postdoc position for Agent-Based Simulations of mixed species biofilm formation.

Postdoc needed with computational/math background to work on agent-based modeling of biofilms.

Abhishekh Gupta joins our team.

Welcome to Dr. Abhishekh Gupta who has joined our team to work on the COPASI project.

New E. coli central metabolism model published.

PLOS Computational Biology article has most accurate E. coli central metabolism model to date.

Postdoc position to develop and implement algorithms for COPASI.

Position now closed.

Pedro Mendes joined University of Connecticut as full-time faculty on July 1, 2016.

New chapter in our group.

Our group is organizing a COPASI Conference, May 12-13, 2016.

2016 Computational Modelling with COPASI.

New paper on network effect of kinetic isotope effects.

We investigate kinetic isotope effects at the systems level.

Postdoc position to work on COPASI in Manchester, UK

Postdoc needed for developing the COPASI software.

Postdoc position in iron metabolism modeling in Farmington, CT

Postdoc needed for modeling iron metabolism using COPASI.

Liver iron model highlighted in BioModels

CMSB 2014

12th International Conference on Computational Methods in Systems Biology.

HARMONY 2014

We are organizing the HARMONY 2014 hackathon here in Manchester.

Pedro Mendes leaves VBI

Pedro Mendes ended his position at VBI at the end of 2013.

Congratulations Dr. Simon Mitchell!

Simon Mitchell successfully defended his thesis entitled "A Computational model of human iron metabolism".

Human metabolic reconstruction published (Recon2)

The metabolic modeling community has curated information from five models to create the most comprehensive model of human metabolism to date.

Detailed model of the translation machinery published

A new publication in Molecular Systems Biology includes a detailed model of translation (the protein synthesis machinery) constructed in our group.

Congratulations Dr. Natalie Stanford!

Natalie Stanford successfully defended her thesis entitled "Towards a full genome-scale model of yeast metabolism".

New article on combinatorial drug design for inflammation

Our work on using evolutionary algorithms to design drug combinations against inflammation has been published in Nature Chemical Biology.

Workshops on Modelling and Simulation using COPASI (USA and UK)

Two 3-day workshops on our software COPASI will be organized in Manchester and Blacksburg this Summer.

Pedro's blog is now active

New blog created for Pedro Mendes.

Workshop on Modelling and Simulation using COPASI, 28-30/07/2009

Manchester Centre for Integrative Systems Biology announces a workshop on Modelling and simulation using COPASI, to take place 28-30 July 2009.

2 Positions Open for Professors in Systems Biology

The University of Manchester and the Manchester Centre for Integrative Systems Biology wish to appoint two new Professors in Systems Biology.

Postdoc position open for IL-1 modelling

A BBSRC-funded Postdoctoral Research Associate position is now open to carry out modelling and simulation of the Interleukin-1 associated network particularly its activation by reactive oxygen species. Candidates are sought with experience of modelling biological systems, particularly with SBML-compliant software such as COPASI or Cell Designer.

SBRML â€” draft proposal for a results markup language

We propose a specification for systems biology modelling results to complement the existing SBML standard. This draft proposal is being made available for discussion, mainly at the SBML Forum in Gothenburg, Sweden (Aug 27-28, 2008). SBRML draft available here.

DREAM competition in silico networks

In silico networks used for the DREAM competition have been unveiled

New website and new location
